title: Hero police officers who arrested accused Christchurch gunman Brenton Tarrant given bravery awards
text:
Heroic police officers who stopped the alleged Christchurch gunman by ramming his car have been given bravery awards.

The police officers put their lives in danger when they dragged Brenton Tarrant from the vehicle, which was allegedly loaded with bombs in the back, and arrested him in Brougham Street on March 15.

The two men, who cannot legally be identified, had been chasing the alleged gunman after two mosques had been shot up - leaving 51 people dead.

Tarrant (pictured) was arrested on the sidewalk by two police officers after he allegedly shot and killed 51 Muslim worshipers

The pair, who have known each other for years and even played rugby together, had spotted the gold Subaru driving erratically through the streets with hazard lights on 18 minutes after the emergency call was made.

The registration number matched the one that had been identified in the alleged shooter's video, where the the alleged gunman had been seen grabbing a rifle from the boot.

After ramming the car, they stormed into action, dragging the driver into the street.

They told reporters it was 'total faith that the other would do their job and continue to go forward regardless of what (they) encountered' that kept them going.

The dramatic arrest was caught on camera by a passerby.

On Wednesday, surrounded by friends, they were recognised for their heroism at a ceremony held in Wellington by the Police Association Conference.

New Zealand's alleged mosque terrorist, Brenton Tarrant, pleaded not guilty to 51 counts of murder, 40 counts of attempted murder and one charge of terrorism

The horrific terror attack in Christchurch, which left 51 worshipers dead, has been described as New Zealand's darkest day

They were presented the award by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, The New Zealand Herald reported.

'We know our families are truly proud of what we were able to do, and that has helped tremendously in the past months.

'For us, knowing we played our part in possibly preventing further casualties is really important.'

Tarrant, an Australian, is currently bejhind bars awaiting trial after he pleaded not guilty to 51 counts of murder, 40 counts of attempted murder and one charge of terrorism.

Tarrant is next due in court on December 12 for a procedural hearing.
